headline: Walmart illegally opened bank accounts for over 1 million drivers, CFPB alleges
summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau sued Walmart and fintech company Branch Messenger for allegedly forcing more than a million delivery workers to use expensive deposit accounts to access their paychecks, the agency announced Monday.

headline: Walmart Stock Falls as CFPB Sues Over Pay Practices for Delivery Drivers
summary: Walmart  stock fell Monday after the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said it was suing the retailer and its fintech partner, Branch Messenger, for illegally opening deposit accounts for more than one million delivery drivers.  Shares of  Walmart  declined 2.1% to $90.33.  The regulator accused Walmart of “forcing delivery drivers to use costly deposit accounts to get paid” and “deceiving” workers about how they could access their earnings.

headline: CFPB accuses Walmart and Branch of opening illegal accounts
summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau sued Walmart and payment app Branch Messenger, accusing them of illegally opening 1 million deposit accounts and charging $10 million in fees. Branch said the agency refused to engage in any meaningful way about the matter.

raw.headline: CFPB accuses Walmart and Branch of opening illegal accounts
raw.summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau sued Walmart and payment app Branch Messenger, accusing them of illegally opening 1 million deposit accounts and charging $10 million in fees. Branch said the agency refused to engage in any meaningful way about the matter.

headline: CFPB vs. Walmart, iPhone 16, Apollo and Workday: Top Stocks
summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) is suing retailer Walmart (WMT) for forcing its delivery drivers to use pricey deposit accounts in order to receive payments. Wedbush senior analyst Dan Ives published a note stating that the global demand for Apple's iPhone 16 (AAPL) has increased slightly above expectations. Apollo Global Management (APO) and Workday (WDAY) have begun trading on the S&P 500 (^GSPC) on Monday. Disclosure: Yahoo Finance is owned by Apollo Global Management. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Wealth here. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

headline: US government sues Walmart, Branch Messenger over delivery driver 'junk fees'
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. consumer finance watchdog accused Walmart and the workforce payments company Branch Messenger on Monday of forcing more than a million delivery drivers into using accounts that cost them more than $10 million in junk fees.  The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said in a lawsuit that Walmart had told "last mile" drivers in its Spark Driver program it would fire them unless they collected their pay in Branch accounts opened without their consent, the agency said.  "Companies cannot force workers into getting paid through accounts that drain their earnings with junk fees," CFPB Director Rohit Chopra said in a statement.

raw.headline: US government sues Walmart, Branch Messenger over delivery driver 'junk fees'
raw.summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. consumer finance watchdog accused Walmart and the workforce payments company Branch Messenger on Monday of forcing more than a million delivery drivers into using accounts that cost them more than $10 million in junk fees.  The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said in a lawsuit that Walmart had told "last mile" drivers in its Spark Driver program it would fire them unless they collected their pay in Branch accounts opened without their consent, the agency said.  "Companies cannot force workers into getting paid through accounts that drain their earnings with junk fees," CFPB Director Rohit Chopra said in a statement.

headline: Amazon vs. Walmart: Which Stock Is the Better Buy for 2025?
summary: A pair of behemoths in the retail space, both Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN) and Walmart (NYSE: WMT) have been strong winners in 2024.  There's no doubt that Amazon has had a major influence on Walmart over the years.  Its online retail platform and logistics network created an existential challenge for Walmart that led the latter company to transform itself into the largest grocery store in the country.

headline: They Helped Create DEI—and Even They Say It Needs a Makeover
summary: DEI is an important response to that history and has accomplished much, despite sometimes uneven execution, says Olivia Christian, who juggles dual careers as a sportscaster and consultant to employee-resource groups for women and people of color at Google,  Visa Amazon  and other firms.  It traces the ebb and flow of corporate diversity efforts, from attempts to comply with President  John F. Kennedy’s  “affirmative action” executive order in the 1960s to recasting diversity as a management strategy in the 1980s, when President  Ronald Reagan  threatened to end affirmative action.  Little wonder the backlash against DEI, led by activist Robby Starbuck, has been so forceful, he says.
